item.title: @TomSkyNews part 4: interviewing looters after the UK riots
item.itunes:author: Paulbradshaw
item.description: Tom Parmenter from Sky News talks to #bcujournos about his interview with looters in the wake of the UK riots: how the interviews were sourced, how they checked their stories, how they tried to protect their identities - and why they decided to do so. You can see the interview here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jg1c6ZY5jFc
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom Parmenter from Sky News talks to #bcujournos about his interview with looters in the wake of the UK riots: how the interviews were sourced, how they checked their stories, how they tried to protect their identities - and why they decided to do so. ...

item.description: Sky News's Tom Parmenter talks to #bcujournos about his first years in the industry, and the background to a report from the Congo which followed a trial in the UK around children suspected of being 'witches'. item.itunes:author: Paulbradshaw
item.description: Founder of the British Asian website @Desiblitz Indi Deol speaks to students at Birmingham City University about his 8 years spent building the site, and why taboos are more important than celebrity in building audiences. 6'20: How would you respond to trending hashtags? 11'20: How have prominent Asian entertainment figures helped bring this culture to a new audience? #indideol

item.title: The Guardian's data projects editor @HelenaBengtsson on working with data
item.itunes:author: Paulbradshaw
item.description:
As part of a visit by @bcumedia MA Online Journalism students to The #Guardian, their data projects editor Helena Bengtsson talks about how data stories are born, pitched and develop at The Guardian; how she works with other teams and colleagues; and how she found stories in Wikileaks data, text data and 19 million rows of housing price data. Contributing questions are students including @barbaramaseda and @catalinalgeorge
Photo by @carlapedret
Link to housing story: http://www.theguardian.com/money/ng-interactive/2015/aug/19/london-rent-rising-interactive?CMP=share_btn_tw

item.title: @mayaruss on the Facebook strategy for @bhameastside
item.itunes:author: Paulbradshaw
item.description: Marianna Russo took on the Facebook page for the news website Birmingham Eastside as part of a project for the MA in Online Journalism at Birmingham City University. During two weeks page likes increased tenfold, and updates reached over 1300 users. She talks about the lessons learned, and the things she should have done more of. #facebook #SMO
item.itunes:subtitle: Marianna Russo took on the Facebook page for the news website Birmingham Eastside as part of a project for the MA in Online Journalism at Birmingham City University. During two weeks page likes increased tenfold, and updates reached over 1300 users. Sh...

During two weeks page likes increased tenfold, and updates reached over 1300 users. She talks about the lessons learned, and the things she should have done more of. #facebook #SMO
item.content:encoded:
Marianna Russo took on the Facebook page for the news website Birmingham Eastside as part of a project for the MA in Online Journalism at Birmingham City University. During two weeks page likes increased tenfold, and updates reached over 1300 users. She talks about the lessons learned, and the things she should have done more of.

#facebook #SMO

item.title: FAQ Boo: How can the future of journalism be online when it is less trusted than print?
item.itunes:author: Paulbradshaw
item.description:
The latest UK research on 'trusted media' suggests that dedicated news websites are more trusted than newspapers: 55% to 38% http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2011/nov/14/phone-hacking-public-trust?CMP=twt_fd
Again, I don't think this sort of research is that helpful, as trust tends to be based on a mixture of factors, including the particular source - one newspaper is more trusted than another, one website more than another; one friend on social media more than a stranger on social media.

item.title: Tools and tips for finding stories in large amounts of text - by Sarah Cohen (GIJC 2011)
item.itunes:author: Paulbradshaw
item.description:
Sarah Cohen is the Knight professor at Duke University. She worked as a database editor at the Washington Post for more than 10 years, where she shared in the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting, the Goldsmith award and the IRE medal. She also has worked as a reporter in Florida and as IRE's training director,
Here she talks at the Global Investigative Journalism Conference, Kiev, Ukraine 2011.
